title: AbstractReferencePropertyType
description: The purpose of this schema is best understood in the context of a columnar dataset: the AbstractReferencePropertyType describes a column in a columnar dataset by declaring its value type (number, string), a UnitQuantity if the value type is a number, a kind if the string value is actually a relationship to a e.g. reference-data type.

ValueType.title: Value Type
ValueType.description: The type of value to expect for this reference property, either "number" (floating point number), "integer",  "string", or "boolean".

ValueCount.title: Value Count
ValueCount.description: The number of values in a tuple, e.g. For coordinates. The default is 1.

UnitQuantityID.title: Unit Quantity ID
UnitQuantityID.description: Only populated of the ValueType is "number". It holds the UnitQuantity associated with this reference property type. It is a relationship to UnitQuantity record.

PropertyType.title: Property Type
PropertyType.description: It holds the PropertyType associated with this reference property type, further defining the semantics of the value. It contains a relationship to PropertyType record and its (de-normalized) name. String or number values can represent e.g. A date or a time by referring to the respective PropertyType record id.

RelationshipTargetKind.title: Relationship Target Kind
RelationshipTargetKind.description: Only populated if ValueType=="string" and the values are expected to represent record ids, e.g. to a reference-data type, then this value holds the kind (optionally without the semantic version number).

FacetIDs.title: Facet IDs
FacetIDs.description:
Ordered array with: FacetType, FacetRole, both calling specific references

FacetType: Enumerations of the type of additional context about the nature of a property type (it may include conditions, direction, qualifiers, or statistics). 

FacetRole: Additional context about the nature of a property type. The purpose of such attribute is to minimize the need to create specialized property types by mutualizing some well known qualifiers such as "maximum", "minimum" which apply to a lot of different property types.
